edge: Although the original Spanish title El laberinto del fauno refers to the fauns of Roman mythology, Guillermo del Toro has stated that the faun in the film is not Pan.
The English, German and French titles of the movie refer specifically to the faun-like Greek deity Pan.
Guillermo del Toro's notebooks filled with doodles, ideas, drawings and plot bits for over twenty years.
The original story by Guillermo del Toro was about a pregnant woman who falls in love with a faun.

Del Toro got the idea of the faun from childhood experiences with "lucid dreaming". Every midnight, he would wake up and a faun would gradually step out from behind the grandfather's clock according to his statement on Charlie Rose.

node_2: half-man, half-goat faun fraught with beauty
edge: Originally, the faun was supposed to be a classic half-man, half-goat faun fraught with beauty.

node_2: goat-faced creature almost completely made out of earth, moss, vines, and tree bark
edge: But in the end, the faun was altered into a goat-faced creature almost completely made out of earth, moss, vines, and tree bark.
He became a mysterious, semi-suspicious relic who gave both the impression of trustworthiness and many signs that warn someone to never confide in him at all.
Del Toro drew inspiration from the figure of god Pan in the works of Borges, Blackwood, Machen, and Dunsany.
Del Toro drew inspiration from the symbol of the labyrinth in the works of Borges, Blackwood, Machen, and Dunsany.
Del Toro drew inspiration from Lewis Carroll's Alice books for Pan's Labyrinth.
Fernando Tielve and Íñigo Garcés, who played the protagonists of The Devil's Backbone, make cameo appearances as unnamed guerrilla soldiers in Pan's Labyrinth.

node_2: informal sequel dealing with some of the issues raised there
edge: Del Toro has said that the film has strong connections in theme to The Devil's Backbone and should be seen as an informal sequel dealing with some of the issues raised there.
Del Toro wanted to include a fairy tale about a dragon for Ofelia to narrate to her unborn brother, which involved the dragon Varanium Silex, named after Rackham's illustration of the same name.

node_2: dragon guarding a mountain surrounded by thorns
edge: In Del Toro's fairy tale, Varanium Silex was the dragon who guarded a mountain surrounded by thorns.

node_2: at the peak of the mountain
edge: At the peak of the mountain, there was a blue rose that could grant immortality.

node_2: decide it is better to avoid pain than to be given immortality
edge: Many men decided it was better to avoid pain than to be granted immortality by the blue rose at the peak of the mountain.
Del Toro considers Pan's Labyrinth a layman's riff on Catholic dogma.
Del Toro's explanation for the Pale Man's preference for children over the feast in front of him is intended as a criticism of the Catholic Church.
Del Toro believes that the fantasy underworld in Pan's Labyrinth is real, but the movie should tell something different to everyone, and there are clues in the movie indicating this.
Del Toro himself has a Catholic background.
Del Toro's friend Alejandro González Iñárritu described Pan's Labyrinth as 'a truly Catholic film'.

node_2: communication to political prisoners during spanish civil war
edge: The priest's words during the torture scene were taken as a direct quote from a priest who offered communion to political prisoners during the Spanish Civil War.
The film was shot in a scots pine forest situated in the Guadarrama mountain range, Central Spain.

Guillermo Navarro, the director of photography, said that "after doing work in Hollywood on other movies and with other directors, working in our original language in different scenery brings me back to the original reasons I wanted to make movies, which is basically to tell stories with complete freedom and to let the visuals really contribute to the telling of the story"

node_2: pale man's eyes on his hands
edge: The pale man's eyes on his hands are a feature shared by the Japanese mythological monster the Tenome (a name which means "hand eyes").
Del Toro himself performed the noises.
The mandrake root is a combination of animatronics and CGI.
Del Toro wanted the fairies "to look like little monkeys, like dirty fairies", but the animation company had the idea to give them wings made of leaves.

Jones spent an average of five hours sitting in the makeup chair as his team applied the makeup for the Faun, which was mostly latex foam. The last piece to be applied was the pair of horns, which weighed ten pounds and were extremely tiring to wear.
The legs of the Faun were attached to Jones' own legs. His lower leg was eventually digitally erased in post-production.
The makeup for the Faun was mostly latex foam, applied by Jones' team of David Martí, Montse Ribé and Xavi Bastida.
The last piece to be applied was the pair of horns, which weighed ten pounds and were extremely tiring to wear.
Jones portrayed the Faun in the movie.
Del Toro said that the Captain's room resembled his troubled mind.
A bout of weight loss on del Toro's part inspired the physical appearance of the saggy-skinned Pale Man.
In order to see while performing the part, Doug Jones had to look out of the character's nostrils.
The film uses subtitles for its translation into other languages, including English.
Del Toro wrote the subtitles himself because he was disappointed with the subtitles of his previous Spanish-language film, The Devil's Backbone.
Del Toro referred to the subtitles of his previous Spanish-language film, The Devil's Backbone, as 'for the thinking impaired'.
Del Toro described the subtitles of his previous Spanish-language film, The Devil's Backbone, as 'incredibly bad'.
Del Toro did not want the subtitles to 'feel like... watching a subtitled film'.
